attributes.title: The effects of a Hausa Language Television Channel on Attitudes in Northern Nigeria

q1.value: The effects of a Hausa Language Television Channel on Attitudes in Northern Nigeria

q5.value: this study is linked to other papers by the authors in northern Nigeria

q9.value: One of our three analyses has already been conducted. For the second, we have the data but have not looked at it. For the third, we have no data but have conducted a small pilot study to develop a protocol for the 6 month long panel experiment.

q15.value: In June of 2014, Equal Access International launched free to air Hausa language television station in Kano, Nigeria, Arewa24. In the context of growing support for violence in Islamic Africa, Equal Access hoped that programming on the channel would diminish popular support for violence and associated religious intolerance or, at least, stem the tide of such support. This channel is the first of its kind, presenting culturally appropriate content in Hausa written, produced, and filmed by veterans of the Hausa-language film industry based in Kano, Nigeria. The intended audience for this channel includes all of Muslim Northern Nigeria. This paper presents a preliminary assessment of the impact of this attempt to use television to change (or resist change) in attitudes in the context of violence and social change in Northern Nigeria and the Muslim world. The channel has 4 prosocial goals: (1) to increase tolerance towards religious and ethnic outgroups; (2) to decrease acceptance for violence as a means to achieve goals; (3) to increase support for the empowerment of women; and (4) increase support for the empowerment of youth. This paper will present three analyses to determine if the channel is having an effect on these three attitudes. First, a matching analysis in which viewers in 2015 are compared with non-viewers in 2015 and non-viewers in 2013. Second, a pre-post survey difference in which individuals and neighborhoods in 2017 are compared to individuals and neighborhoods in 2014. And third, a randomized encouragement experiment in which treatment subjects are encouraged to watch an Arewa24 program, placebo subjects are encouraged to watch a rival network, and control subjects are not encouraged to change their viewing habits. To be clear: the first matching analysis of 2015 viewers with 2015 and 2013 non-viewers is already underway; this registration is retrospective for that analysis. This registration is prospective for the pre/post survey comparison -- we have the data but have not yet looked at it. And the analysis is prospective for the randomized encouragement experiment -- we have only conducted a small pilot study to test the IVR system and develop a protocol for how to conduct a large-scale, 6 month panel experiment using IVR technology. (the following was added to this registration on 26 August 2017) We are now adding a fourth analysis for which we have not analyzed any data. This is an IVR difference-in-differences design where "control" observations are those who call into Arewa24's inbound line in the two hours before their flagship prosocial program airs, and "treatment" observations are those who call into Arewa24's inbound line in the two hours after their flagship prosocial program airs.

q16.value: We hypothesize that Arewa24 viewers, compared to non-viewers, are: (1) more tolerant of religious and ethnic outgroups (2) less supportive of violence (3) more supportive of women's empowerment (4) more supportive of youth empowerment We believe these effects will be strongest among youth, who should have less ingrained attitudes, and strongest for those who view the channel most frequently. We also believe we will see the strongest effect on women's empowerment for women, and the strongest effect on youth empowerment for youth. For our observational study comparing neighborhoods in 2015 with those same neighborhoods in 2017, we hypothesize that: (5) Neighborhood level tolerance, nonviolence, women's empowerment, and youth empowerment increase proportional to the % of Arewa24 viewers in that neighborhood. (the following was added to this registration on 26 August 2017) For the difference-in-differences design (added later), we predict that people who call into the Arewa24 inbound line after the show airs will be more supportive of that particular show's messages than people who call into Arewa24 before the show airs.

q17.value: These hypotheses will be tested with a four prong study. First, a matching analysis that compares viewers in 2015 with non-viewers in 2015 and non-viewers in 2013. A large-scale survey was undertaken by the US Department of State in 2013, before Arewa24 launched. That same survey, plus questions relating to Arewa24, was conducted again in late 2015, after the channel had been airing content for more than 1 year. We first match 2015 viewers with 2015 non-viewers and compare the differences on our four outcomes of interest (tolerance, violence, women's empowerment, youth empowerment). We then match 2015 viewers with 2013 non-viewers and compare them in a difference-in-differences design with 2015 non-viewers. This difference-in-differences should account for changes over time that occur orthogonal to Arewa24. The analysis will match on every variable we think could affect viewing Arewa24, missingness on those variables, and the proportions of those variables in the individual's neighborhood. From that list, we will use a LASSO to select variables that do predict viewing Arewa24. Second, we will analyze a pre/post survey conducted in conjunction with Arewa24. Arewa24 conducted a baseline survey in late 2014, just before it began airing its flagship, award-winning drama program, Dadin Kowa. Arewa24 then conducted an endline survey in early 2017, going to the same neighborhoods and, where possible, talking with the same people. We will compare these neighborhoods over time, conditional on the percentage of Arewa24 viewers (expecting more change in places with more Arewa24 viewers). We will also compare the people we were able to contact at both times points (2015 and 2017). And we will compare Arewa24 viewers to non-Arewa24 viewers, perhaps using matching to make clear comparisons. And perhaps a difference-in-differences design, predicting that Arewa24 viewers will change more than non-Arewa24 viewers over this period of time. Third, we will conduct a randomized encouragement experiment using Interactive Voice Response (IVR) technology. We will encourage people in Northern Nigeria to watch either (1) Dadin Kowa, Arewa24's flagship program, or (2) AIT, a rival channel; a control group (3) will not be asked to change their viewing habits. We will assign viewers in blocks based on their previous exposure to Arewa24 and their gender, since we believe men and women will respond differently to the program, especially to the women's empowerment programming. We will compare people in different experimental groups with an intent-to-treat framework, as well as conditioning on compliance with treatment. We also plan to use the NPC package to account for our multiple coherent hypotheses. (the following was added to this registration on 26 August 2017) Fourth, we use a difference-in-differences design to compare attitudes of Arewa24 viewers just before and just after Arewa24's flagship prosocial program airs. Arewa24 has an inbound call line, and we will compare the attitudes of people who call in the two hours before their flagship program airs with people who call in the two hours after the flagship program airs. If this program is having an effect, we expect more positive attitudes after the program than before it. We will assess parallel trends (that these two groups would be the same if not for the treatment show) with other inbound callers. We will compare people who call in and answer questions on a different day but during the same times. Since the show airs on Saturdays at 8pm, we can compare people who call in on Fridays and Sundays before/after 8pm.

registration_responses.q1: The effects of a Hausa Language Television Channel on Attitudes in Northern Nigeria
registration_responses.q5: this study is linked to other papers by the authors in northern Nigeria
registration_responses.q9: One of our three analyses has already been conducted. For the second, we have the data but have not looked at it. For the third, we have no data but have conducted a small pilot study to develop a protocol for the 6 month long panel experiment.
registration_responses.q15: In June of 2014, Equal Access International launched free to air Hausa language television station in Kano, Nigeria, Arewa24. In the context of growing support for violence in Islamic Africa, Equal Access hoped that programming on the channel would diminish popular support for violence and associated religious intolerance or, at least, stem the tide of such support. This channel is the first of its kind, presenting culturally appropriate content in Hausa written, produced, and filmed by veterans of the Hausa-language film industry based in Kano, Nigeria. The intended audience for this channel includes all of Muslim Northern Nigeria. This paper presents a preliminary assessment of the impact of this attempt to use television to change (or resist change) in attitudes in the context of violence and social change in Northern Nigeria and the Muslim world. The channel has 4 prosocial goals: (1) to increase tolerance towards religious and ethnic outgroups; (2) to decrease acceptance for violence as a means to achieve goals; (3) to increase support for the empowerment of women; and (4) increase support for the empowerment of youth. This paper will present three analyses to determine if the channel is having an effect on these three attitudes. First, a matching analysis in which viewers in 2015 are compared with non-viewers in 2015 and non-viewers in 2013. Second, a pre-post survey difference in which individuals and neighborhoods in 2017 are compared to individuals and neighborhoods in 2014. And third, a randomized encouragement experiment in which treatment subjects are encouraged to watch an Arewa24 program, placebo subjects are encouraged to watch a rival network, and control subjects are not encouraged to change their viewing habits. To be clear: the first matching analysis of 2015 viewers with 2015 and 2013 non-viewers is already underway; this registration is retrospective for that analysis. This registration is prospective for the pre/post survey comparison -- we have the data but have not yet looked at it. And the analysis is prospective for the randomized encouragement experiment -- we have only conducted a small pilot study to test the IVR system and develop a protocol for how to conduct a large-scale, 6 month panel experiment using IVR technology. (the following was added to this registration on 26 August 2017) We are now adding a fourth analysis for which we have not analyzed any data. This is an IVR difference-in-differences design where "control" observations are those who call into Arewa24's inbound line in the two hours before their flagship prosocial program airs, and "treatment" observations are those who call into Arewa24's inbound line in the two hours after their flagship prosocial program airs.
registration_responses.q16: We hypothesize that Arewa24 viewers, compared to non-viewers, are: (1) more tolerant of religious and ethnic outgroups (2) less supportive of violence (3) more supportive of women's empowerment (4) more supportive of youth empowerment We believe these effects will be strongest among youth, who should have less ingrained attitudes, and strongest for those who view the channel most frequently. We also believe we will see the strongest effect on women's empowerment for women, and the strongest effect on youth empowerment for youth. For our observational study comparing neighborhoods in 2015 with those same neighborhoods in 2017, we hypothesize that: (5) Neighborhood level tolerance, nonviolence, women's empowerment, and youth empowerment increase proportional to the % of Arewa24 viewers in that neighborhood. (the following was added to this registration on 26 August 2017) For the difference-in-differences design (added later), we predict that people who call into the Arewa24 inbound line after the show airs will be more supportive of that particular show's messages than people who call into Arewa24 before the show airs.
registration_responses.q17: These hypotheses will be tested with a four prong study. First, a matching analysis that compares viewers in 2015 with non-viewers in 2015 and non-viewers in 2013. A large-scale survey was undertaken by the US Department of State in 2013, before Arewa24 launched. That same survey, plus questions relating to Arewa24, was conducted again in late 2015, after the channel had been airing content for more than 1 year. We first match 2015 viewers with 2015 non-viewers and compare the differences on our four outcomes of interest (tolerance, violence, women's empowerment, youth empowerment). We then match 2015 viewers with 2013 non-viewers and compare them in a difference-in-differences design with 2015 non-viewers. This difference-in-differences should account for changes over time that occur orthogonal to Arewa24. The analysis will match on every variable we think could affect viewing Arewa24, missingness on those variables, and the proportions of those variables in the individual's neighborhood. From that list, we will use a LASSO to select variables that do predict viewing Arewa24. Second, we will analyze a pre/post survey conducted in conjunction with Arewa24. Arewa24 conducted a baseline survey in late 2014, just before it began airing its flagship, award-winning drama program, Dadin Kowa. Arewa24 then conducted an endline survey in early 2017, going to the same neighborhoods and, where possible, talking with the same people. We will compare these neighborhoods over time, conditional on the percentage of Arewa24 viewers (expecting more change in places with more Arewa24 viewers). We will also compare the people we were able to contact at both times points (2015 and 2017). And we will compare Arewa24 viewers to non-Arewa24 viewers, perhaps using matching to make clear comparisons. And perhaps a difference-in-differences design, predicting that Arewa24 viewers will change more than non-Arewa24 viewers over this period of time. Third, we will conduct a randomized encouragement experiment using Interactive Voice Response (IVR) technology. We will encourage people in Northern Nigeria to watch either (1) Dadin Kowa, Arewa24's flagship program, or (2) AIT, a rival channel; a control group (3) will not be asked to change their viewing habits. We will assign viewers in blocks based on their previous exposure to Arewa24 and their gender, since we believe men and women will respond differently to the program, especially to the women's empowerment programming. We will compare people in different experimental groups with an intent-to-treat framework, as well as conditioning on compliance with treatment. We also plan to use the NPC package to account for our multiple coherent hypotheses. (the following was added to this registration on 26 August 2017) Fourth, we use a difference-in-differences design to compare attitudes of Arewa24 viewers just before and just after Arewa24's flagship prosocial program airs. Arewa24 has an inbound call line, and we will compare the attitudes of people who call in the two hours before their flagship program airs with people who call in the two hours after the flagship program airs. If this program is having an effect, we expect more positive attitudes after the program than before it. We will assess parallel trends (that these two groups would be the same if not for the treatment show) with other inbound callers. We will compare people who call in and answer questions on a different day but during the same times. Since the show airs on Saturdays at 8pm, we can compare people who call in on Fridays and Sundays before/after 8pm.

attributes.title: How Social Elites and Social Peers Moderate Social Learning

q1.value: How Social Elites and Social Peers Moderate Social Learning

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: We have been assessing the effects of Arewa24, a prosocial Hausa language television station in northern Nigeria, on attitudes of people in northern Nigeria. Arewa24 was launched with the goal of increasing tolerance for outgroups, decreasing the acceptance of violence, and increasing support for the empowerment of women and youth. For this study we are interested in the effect of social environment on the effects of Arewa24. We conducted survey interviews in 60 communities and were able to survey the community's traditional leaders in each of these communities. We believe that Arewa24 will have the largest effect where (1) the community leader is amenable to the message, and (2) the wider community is amenable to the message. We also wish to test for "backlash effects" wherein very intolerant people in communities with many Arewa24 become more intolerant. Lastly, we wish to test the idea that Arewa24 triggers social conversations about a topic, causing the variance in attitudes of a community to decrease as the proportion of Arewa24 viewers increases. If Arewa24 causes social discussion in a community, we believe that the community members will come to a community consensus about the issue.

q16.value: (1) Arewa24 viewers will be more tolerant, less accepting of violence, and more supportive of women and youth empowerment than non-viewers (this will be tested in a different paper). (2) Arewa24 will have a stronger effect on attitudes in communities with a community leader who is tolerant, not violence-accepting, and supportive of women's and youth's empowerment. (3) The effect of viewing Arewa24 on an individual will increase as the proportion of Arewa24 viewers in a community increases. (4) For individual's who are very intolerant/violence-accepting/un-supportive of women & youth empowerment, their attitudes become stronger as the proportion of Arewa24 viewers in their community increases (backlash effect) (5) The effect of viewing Arewa24 on an individual's tolerance/violence/women's empowerment/youth empowerment will increase as the individual's social environment becomes more accepting of those attitudes, but the effect is curvilinear; Arewa24 has no effect in very intolerant neighborhoods, maximal effect in moderate neighborhoods who are open to change, and no effect in very tolerant neighborhoods due to a ceiling effect. (6) The more Arewa24 viewers in a community, the more homogeneity of community opinion about tolerance, violence, and the support for women's and youth's empowerment. (consensus effect)

q17.value: A survey of 60 communities with 25 individual's per community + the community's traditional leader. These communities were surveyed in 2014 for a baseline survey, and in 2017 we conducted an endline survey, adding the community leader interviews. We plan to use OLS, as it is an unbiased and consistent estimator for differences between groups. We plan to use HC2 standard errors, conduct shuffle/permutation tests for p-values, and utilize NPC for testing multiple outcomes at once.

attributes.title: Effects of schemata on variation (lexical decision)

q1.value: Examining effects of schemata on German masculine nouns using a lexical decision task

q3.value:
The influence of schemata on the inflection of masculine nouns in German has been well examined in corpora (Köpcke 1995, 2000a, 2000b, 2005, Schäfer 2016). Prototypically, polysyllabic nouns stressed on the penultimate syllable ending with schwa and referring to human beings belong to the so-called weak declension class. Variation can be observed if a noun diverges from the formal (polysyllabic, stress on the penultimate syllable, schwa) or semantic (referring to human beings) features: These nouns vary between weak and strong forms. The strong conjugation class is the type frequent class concerning masculine nouns. Besides the schema of weak nouns, token frequency influences the membership of classes: Token frequent nouns are more likely to stay in the weak class than token infrequent nouns (Schäfer 2016).

To my knowledge, psycholinguistic studies concerning this topic are missing so far. Psycholinguistic studies on declension in German examine, e.g., the processing of regular and irregular plural forms (Penke and Krause 2002; Sonnenstuhl and Huth 2002) but do not examine effects of schemata. An exception to this is Schmitt (2019). Here, effects of schemata are examined with the help of a self-paced reading task using pseudo nouns. Schmitt (2019) could not measure differences between reading times for weak and strong genitive endings of the pseudo noun "Schettose" which perfectly matches the schema of the weak masculine class and thus should facilitate the processing of weak endings. An effect of schemata is therefore not observable in reaction times. However, participants had a clear preference for the weak ending in the production task within the study. Hence, there seems to be conflicting evidence for effects of schemata. 

This study aims to further examine effects of schemata with the help of a lexical decision task. Participants judge weak (-n) and strong (-s) genitive forms of real existing nouns (des Kollegen/Kolleges 'the colleague.GEN'). Each test word is presented twice, once with a  weak suffix and once with a strong suffix, so that both forms are judged.  Hence, the design allows to test the influence of infrequent and thus unexpected suffixes (e.g., a strong suffix for a noun belonging to the weak declension class) on reaction times. 

The test words belong to the schema of the weak declension class to different degrees: nouns that fully match the schema are compared to nouns that are in the periphery of the schema as they do not meet the schema’s formal criteria. Additionally, nouns are used that do not belong to the weak declension class but are similar to the nouns belonging to the periphery of the schema. The degree of animacy of the test nouns is constant, as the test items refer to human beings. The token frequency of the test nouns was controlled as well: all test nouns have a relative frequency of max. 2 hits per million tokens.

The study design allows to test the influence of schemata on processing as well as the influence of forms that are typcially used or typically not used with the test words.

q4.value:
1. reaction times

An interaction between schematicity and inflection is expected. Reaction times are expected to be fast for the combination of weak inflection and nouns that prototypically or peripherally belong to the schema of weak masculine nouns and for the combination of strong inflection and nouns belonging to the strong declination class. Reaction times are expected to be higher if strong inflection and nouns belonging to the schema (prototypically and peripherally) are combined and weak inflection and strong masculine nouns. Hence, the degree of schematicity does not influence the reaction times. This hypothesis is based on the results of a prestudy (see data_prestudy_schema_decision.csv for the data and prestudy_schema_decision.R for the code analysing the data). Originally, an effect of schematicity was expected for reaction times: Higher reaction times were expected for nouns in the periphery as theoretically more than one form can be produced. The opposite was expected for nouns belonging to the strong class or to the prototype of the schema as here only one possible form exists (see https://osf.io/834nz for the preregistration of the prestudy).

2. acceptance of strong and weak inflection

The acceptance of the weak inflection (-n) depends on the form of the noun. If the form matches the criteria of weak masculine nouns completely, -n will be accepted. Weak endings of nouns that do not belong to the weak class will not be accepted. The opposite is expected regarding strong inflection (-s). For nouns in the periphery, acceptance for both endings is expected. However, it is expected that weak endings will show a higher acceptance rate (100 %) than strong endings (ca. 50%). Again, this distribution was observable for the data of the prestudy.
It is hypothesized that participants judge the nouns belonging to the schema and those not belonging to the weak class consistently, whereas inconsistent answers are expected for the nouns in the periphery of the schema. This should be observable in the distributions of answers (no clearly distributed response behaviour for nouns in the periphery, predominately acceptance for weak forms but rejection for strong forms regarding nouns belonging to the schema and vice versa for nouns not belonging to the weak declension class) as well as for individual participants (rejection/acceptance for both forms in the periphery, opposite answers to weak and strong forms of a single test noun for nouns belonging to the schema/not belonging to the weak declension class).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
A within subject design is used with two factors (schematicity and inflection) with three levels (prototype the schema, periphery of the schema, not belonging to the weak class) and two levels (weak, strong), respectively. Per level of schematicity, five test words are used. The test words are presented with weak as well as strong inflection (e.g., des Kollegen/des Kolleges) and participants are asked to decide whether they know the word ("Kennen Sie dieses Wort bzw. diese Wortabfolge?" 'Do you know this word/ word sequence?'). The answer (yes/no) as well as the reaction times are used for data analysis. 
Verbs belonging to the strong conjugation class with weak and strong inflection are used as fillers. They serve as test items for a study on the influence of frequency on variation. Additionally, strong genitive forms ending with -es are used as fillers. The genitive form -es is used for nouns that normally have -s as genitive ending as they do not allow -es phonotactically (*des Abendes 'the evening.GEN') (Szczepaniak 2010).  
To test the design, reaction times elicited by long (-es) and short (-s) genitive endings of two nouns not allowing long genitive endings are contrasted (Ultimatum, Internet) as well as reaction times elicited by regular and irregular forms of the irregular verbs "gehen" 'to go' and "bringen" 'to bring'. These items will only be relevant if the statistical analysis of the test items does not hint to differences in reaction times.  The items allow to test whether the design can elicit differences in reaction times in general. The following mixed linear model will be used  if the design needs to be tested: reaction time ~ acceptance + (1|item)+(1+acceptance|participant). Acceptance is the manipulated variable. The variabel has two levels: accepted (short ending/irregular form) and not accepted (long ending/regular form). Additionally, the response behaviour (yes/no) of the participants will be analysed with the following logistic mixed linear model (response ~ acceptance + (1|item)+(1+form|participant). 

PsychoPy3, version 3.1.5,  (Peirce 2019) is used to implement the study. 

Test items

Prototype of the schema: Franzose ‘frenchman’, Geselle ‘journeyman’, Kollege ‘colleague’, Neffe ‘nephew‘, Schütze ‘marksman‘ 

Periphery of the schema: Fürst ‘ruler’, Graf ‘count’, Held ‘hero’, Nachbar ‘neighbor’, Zar ‘tsar’, 

Not belonging to the weak declension class: Dieb ‘thief’, Feind ‘enemy’, Freund ‘friend’, Kerl ‘guy’, Vogt ‘reeve’

In order to avoid frequency effects, nouns are used that have a frequency of up to two hits per million tokens in 2018 in the word frequencies provided by digital dictionary for the German language (Digitales Wörterbuch der Deutschen Sprache, Berlin-Brandenburgische Akademie der Wissenschaften). However, there are slight differences in frequency within the test words: Three nouns that prototypically match the schema have a frequency of 0.4 to 1.6 hits per million tokens but the other two are less frequent (up to 0.05 hits per million tokens). The words that are in the periphery of the schema have a frequency of 0.3 to 0.9 hits per million tokens. Two of the words not belonging to the weak class have a comparable frequency (0.3 to 0.5 hits per million tokens), but the other three are far less frequent (up to 0.04 hits per million tokens). Hence, the nouns not belonging to the weak declension class tend to be less frequent than the other test words. However, "des Gesellen" and "des Neffen", belonging to the prototype of the schema, are comparable infrequent as these nouns. All in all, the token frequencies of the test words are on a comparable level. Note, however, that the prestudy of a similar experiment using a sentence maze task indicated effects of frequency despite trying to control for frequency (see https://osf.io/bhxpz for the preregistration of the main study for the sentence maze study). 
As the prestudy of the present study does not point to differences due to frequency (see Exploratory Analysis, data_prestudy_schema_decision.csv for the data as well as prestudy_schema_decision.R for the code), an influence of frequency is not expected for the main study but will be tested within an exploratory analysis. See the attached file (testwords.csv) for an overview over the test words and their relative frequencies.

The frequency of the test nouns is estimated using the word frequencies for the year 2018 provided by the Digital Dictionary of the German Language (Digitales Wörterbuch der Deutschen Sprache, Berlin-Brandenburgische Akademie der Wissenschaften). Test nouns are searched in the genitive singular (with the more frequently used ending). In order to avoid false positives, determiners are used in the search (e.g. @des @Kollegen ‘the colleague’).

The attached file (stimulus file.csv) gives an overview over stimuli and filler items. The file contains the following columns:

Stimulus_Art: unique coding for each stimulus 	
Stimulus: the stimulus as presented to the participant	
Schema: coding for the masculine test nouns; levels: Schema, Peripherie, nichtschwach
Frequenz: coding for the test verbs; levels: frequent, infrequ_m, infrequ_o (not relevant for this study)
Akzeptanz: coding for the items testing the design; levels: nichtakzeptiert, akzeptiert	
Evaluation: "ev" highlights the items evaluating the concentration of the participants (if over 10 % of the nouns have been answered wrong, participant will be excluded)	
Flexion: coding for the test verbs and nouns; levels: stark/schwach	
Item: naming the test items in their base form (test nouns and strong verbs which are not relevant for this study)
Formakzeptiert: (expected) acceptence/inacceptance of the forms, j (yes), n (no), b (both)
correctKey: correct response key (based on Fromakzeptiert); levels: f (no), j (yes, both)
Block: block in which the item is presented	
PositionimBlock: position within the block

Further explanation for the columns "Formakzeptiert" and "correctKey": For the test nouns, the coding of these columns followed the hypotheses. For the level "Schema", weak forms were coded as accepted and strong forms as not accepted. The opposite pattern was used for the level "nichtschwach". For "Peripherie" both forms were coded as accepted.

q9.value: The test items are organized in four blocks. Each block consists of 25 items. In each block, seven to eight test items (two to three test items per level) are included. Strong and weak forms of a single test noun never occur in one block but are spread across blocks. The order of the items within the blocks is constant. The blocks appear in randomized order. The random order is created by randomizing the loops in PsychoPy3.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited by asking teachers at German universities to distribute the study among their students. If necessary, participants will be addionally recruited out of the personal sphere of the author. The participation in the study is voluntary. The participants will not be paid for participating in the study. Participants are informed that their data is stored and analysed anonymously. Participants that are bilingual (defined as having acquired more than one language before the twelfth year of life), do not speak German as their L1 or have dyslexia will be excluded from the study. Additionally, participants will be excluded whose response behaviour points to them not focussing on the task. This evaluation will be based on 31 items. For these items, participants should not vary in their answers (the 31 items are fillers as well as words that are used in the example block and words that are used to evaluate the design of the study). The cut-off point is set to 10 %. Hence, participants that answer three items or more in the opposite way will be excluded from the study. In addition, participants whose reaction times are above 3 sd of the mean reaction times of a level of the category schematicity (e.g., Schema/Peripherie) are excluded from the sample.
If the design has to be tested (see study design for further explanations), only the filler items as well as the items from the example block will be used to evaluate the participants' reponse behaviour. These are 23 items, hence, the cut-off point will be set to 2 or more items that have been answered in the opposite way in this case.

The study is carried out online using the platform pavlovia.org. The git-project with code and stimulus files can be viewed at https://gitlab.pavlovia.org/eleonore/decision.

q13.value:
A sample size of 50 participants is targeted. To reach this number, 100 participants will be recruited. In the prestudy, 12 of 32 participants (38 %) had to be excluded due to missing meta data, response behaviour indicating a lack of concentration and reaction times above 3 sd of the mean reaction times of a level of the category schematicity (e.g., schema). Hence, 50 % more data are collected in order to reach the targeted 50 participants.

See https://osf.io/834nz for the preregistration of the prestudy.  Deviating from the preregistration of the prestudy, participants were exluded if 10 % of the items evaluating the concentration of the participants were answered incorrectly. Additionally, participants werde excluded whose reaction times were above 3 sd from the mean reaction times for a level of the category schematicity (e.g., schema).

q14.value:
The sample size is set to 50 participants based on a power analysis for the reaction times: 50 participants are required to reach a power of over 0.8 for an alpha level of 0.01 for the estimates 0.22 for the level combination "notweak:weak", 0.14 for the level combination "schema: strong", 0.14 for the level combination "periphery:strong" and -0.42 for the level combination "notweak:strong" of the categories schematicity and inflection.  The estimates were computed with a mixed linear model analysing the data of the prestudy. The data of the prestudy (data_prestudy_schema_decision.csv) as well as the code (prestudy_schema_decision.R) analysing the data is attached. See https://osf.io/834nz for the preregistered analysis plan of the prestudy. The code for the data simulation (power analysis_schema_decision.R) calculating the power based on the estimates of the prestudy for 50 particpants is attached as well. The simulation was repeated 10000 times, a file with 10000 repitions of the simulation is attached (sims_schema_dec.csv). See section "statistical models" for the attached files. The code for the data simulation is based on a tutorial for power analyses with R by DeBruine and Barr (preprint).
Note that the power analysis is based on a model that only uses random intercepts, as the model had convergence issues when random slopes were used. For the main study, random slopes for participants will be included into the modell (see analysis plan).

question.value: The schematicity is manipulated by choosing test words that match the schema of weak masculine nouns to different degrees. Three levels are used for this categorial variable: prototype of the schema, periphery of the schema, not belonging to the weak declension class (see study design for an explanation of the levels). The inflection of the test words is manipulated as well. The two levels of this nominal variable are weak and strong.

The outcome variables are the response behaviour (yes/no) and the reaction times for weak and strong forms of masculine nouns belonging to the weak declension class to different degrees (see manipulated variable). This is measured by showing participants weak and strong forms of the test nouns and asking them "Kennen Sie dieses Wort bzw. diese Wortabfolge?" 'Do you know this word/word sequence?'. Additionally to the response behaviour, the time elapsing from the stimulus onset to the response will be measured. 

Meta data (age, gender, dyslexia, educational level, handedness, mother tongue, predominantly speaking dialect or standard, speaking dialect in general, if dialect, which dialect, origin (county, city), current place of residence, intensity of reading (daily, weekly, monthly) is collected. The meta data is used to exclude particpiants from the study (see data collection procedures). It is not used for confirmatory analysis.

For the analysis, R and Rstudio are used (R Core Team 2019, RStudio Team 2015). For the prestudy and the main study, the same version of R and Rstudio are used.

Reaction Times

To calculate the differences in reaction times, a mixed linear model is used. The schematicity of the nouns (prototype of the schema, periphery of the schema, not belonging to the weak class) and the forms (strong, weak) will be included as fixed effects that may interact (high reaction times for nouns that prototypically match the schema with strong endings but low reaction times for the same nouns with weak endings). Item and participant are included as random effects. For participants, random intercepts and random slopes are included, for items only random intercepts as they vary across the levels of the category schematicity. The independent variables are schematicity and the forms. Reaction times are the dependent variable.

Reaction time ~ schematicity * form + (1|item)+ (1+schematicity|participant)

If the model fails to converge, random slopes will be dropped so that only random intercepts are part of the model. 

Acceptance

To evaluate the differences in acceptance (yes/no), a logistic mixed linear model is used. Forms (strong, weak) as well as schematicity (prototype of the schema, periphery of the schema, not belonging to the weak class) are included as fixed effects that may interact (rejection of weak inflection for a noun not belonging to the weak class but not for a noun that matches the schema prototypically). Item and participant are included as random effects. Again, participants are included with random intercepts and random slopes; items only with random intercepts. The independent variables are schematicity and the forms. Acceptance (yes/no) is the dependent variable.

acceptance ~ schematicity * form + (1|item)+ (1+schematicity|participant)

If the model fails to converge, random slopes will be dropped so that only random intercepts are part of the model.

In the prestudy, convergence issues were reported for the generalized linear model so that items had to be dropped as random effect completely (see prestudy_schema_decision.R). Therefore, a conditional inference tree as well as a random forest were calculated additionally. This method will also be used in the main study if the same problems arise for the generalized mixed linear model.

Within the tree and the forest, schematicity as well as inflection will be included as factors:

Key ~ Schema + Inflection

For the tree and the forest, the same code will be used as indicated in the file prestudy_schema_decision.R.

q20.value: If the model for analysing the reaction times does not meet the condition of homoscedasticity and normal distribution of residuals, the reaction times will be transformed into log-reaction times.

q21.value: The alpha-level is set to .01. Based on the estimates of the prestudy, an R2m of .09 and an R2c of .28  is expected.

q22.value: As explained in the data collection procedures, participants will be excluded that do not speak German as their L1, are bilingual or have dyslexia. Additionally, the response bevaviour of the participants will be evaluated and data exclusion will be based on this evaluation. In addition, participants whose reaction time is over 3 sd above the mean of reaction times for a level of the category schematicity (e.g. periphery), will be excluded.

q23.value: Incomplete data sets of participants will not be included into the study. Participants with missing meta data will still be analysed (except for missing information on L1 and dyslexia).

q24.value:
In order to contrast the variation that can be observed for masculine nouns with verbs that vary between strong and weak inflection, test items will be contrasted with the filler items containing strong verbs. See https://osf.io/ynvb5 for the preregistration of a study examining frequency effects for strong verbs that are used as fillers within the present study.

For this comparison, the reaction times elicited by masculine nouns with different degrees of schematicity and strong verbs with different degrees of frequency will be contrasted. In a mixed linear model, part of speech  (noun/verb) and form will be included as fixed effect. In order to include frequency and schematicity levels into the model, the levels will be recoded as category with level one (frequent|schema), level two (infrequent with variation |periphery) and level three (infrequent without variation | notweak). The category "category" will be included as fixed effect. All fixed effects may interact. Participants and items will be included as random effects. Participants will be included with random slopes and random intercepts, whereas items will only be included with random intercepts because items vary across categories.

RT~pos*inflection*category + (1|item) + (1+pos|participant)

As frequency seems to influence the distribution of reaction times in a similar study using a sentence maze task (see https://osf.io/bhxpz for the preregistration of the study), the test items of the present study will be divided into different frequency levels in order to evaluate the influence of frequency. The frequency levels will be "frequent", "middlefrequent" and "infrequent", the items will be distributed based on their relative frequency into the levels so that each level contains five items (see prestudy_schema_decision.R). 
Frequency will be included as fixed effect into a mixed linear model. Additionally, inflection will be included as fixed effect. The fixed effects may interact. Participant and item will be included as random effects. Participants will be included with random slopes and random intercepts, whereas items will only be included with random intercepts because items vary across categories.

RT ~ Frequency * Inflection (1+Frequency|Participant)+(1| Item).

A similar model (without random slopes for participants because of singular fit) has been computed for the data of the prestudy. Here, changes in frequency levels only had small estimates whereas changes of inflection had greater estimates. See prestudy_schema_decision.R for the code.

registration_responses.q1: Examining effects of schemata on German masculine nouns using a lexical decision task
registration_responses.q3:
The influence of schemata on the inflection of masculine nouns in German has been well examined in corpora (Köpcke 1995, 2000a, 2000b, 2005, Schäfer 2016). Prototypically, polysyllabic nouns stressed on the penultimate syllable ending with schwa and referring to human beings belong to the so-called weak declension class. Variation can be observed if a noun diverges from the formal (polysyllabic, stress on the penultimate syllable, schwa) or semantic (referring to human beings) features: These nouns vary between weak and strong forms. The strong conjugation class is the type frequent class concerning masculine nouns. Besides the schema of weak nouns, token frequency influences the membership of classes: Token frequent nouns are more likely to stay in the weak class than token infrequent nouns (Schäfer 2016).

To my knowledge, psycholinguistic studies concerning this topic are missing so far. Psycholinguistic studies on declension in German examine, e.g., the processing of regular and irregular plural forms (Penke and Krause 2002; Sonnenstuhl and Huth 2002) but do not examine effects of schemata. An exception to this is Schmitt (2019). Here, effects of schemata are examined with the help of a self-paced reading task using pseudo nouns. Schmitt (2019) could not measure differences between reading times for weak and strong genitive endings of the pseudo noun "Schettose" which perfectly matches the schema of the weak masculine class and thus should facilitate the processing of weak endings. An effect of schemata is therefore not observable in reaction times. However, participants had a clear preference for the weak ending in the production task within the study. Hence, there seems to be conflicting evidence for effects of schemata. 

This study aims to further examine effects of schemata with the help of a lexical decision task. Participants judge weak (-n) and strong (-s) genitive forms of real existing nouns (des Kollegen/Kolleges 'the colleague.GEN'). Each test word is presented twice, once with a  weak suffix and once with a strong suffix, so that both forms are judged.  Hence, the design allows to test the influence of infrequent and thus unexpected suffixes (e.g., a strong suffix for a noun belonging to the weak declension class) on reaction times. 

The test words belong to the schema of the weak declension class to different degrees: nouns that fully match the schema are compared to nouns that are in the periphery of the schema as they do not meet the schema’s formal criteria. Additionally, nouns are used that do not belong to the weak declension class but are similar to the nouns belonging to the periphery of the schema. The degree of animacy of the test nouns is constant, as the test items refer to human beings. The token frequency of the test nouns was controlled as well: all test nouns have a relative frequency of max. 2 hits per million tokens.

The study design allows to test the influence of schemata on processing as well as the influence of forms that are typcially used or typically not used with the test words.
registration_responses.q4:
1. reaction times

An interaction between schematicity and inflection is expected. Reaction times are expected to be fast for the combination of weak inflection and nouns that prototypically or peripherally belong to the schema of weak masculine nouns and for the combination of strong inflection and nouns belonging to the strong declination class. Reaction times are expected to be higher if strong inflection and nouns belonging to the schema (prototypically and peripherally) are combined and weak inflection and strong masculine nouns. Hence, the degree of schematicity does not influence the reaction times. This hypothesis is based on the results of a prestudy (see data_prestudy_schema_decision.csv for the data and prestudy_schema_decision.R for the code analysing the data). Originally, an effect of schematicity was expected for reaction times: Higher reaction times were expected for nouns in the periphery as theoretically more than one form can be produced. The opposite was expected for nouns belonging to the strong class or to the prototype of the schema as here only one possible form exists (see https://osf.io/834nz for the preregistration of the prestudy).

2. acceptance of strong and weak inflection

The acceptance of the weak inflection (-n) depends on the form of the noun. If the form matches the criteria of weak masculine nouns completely, -n will be accepted. Weak endings of nouns that do not belong to the weak class will not be accepted. The opposite is expected regarding strong inflection (-s). For nouns in the periphery, acceptance for both endings is expected. However, it is expected that weak endings will show a higher acceptance rate (100 %) than strong endings (ca. 50%). Again, this distribution was observable for the data of the prestudy.
It is hypothesized that participants judge the nouns belonging to the schema and those not belonging to the weak class consistently, whereas inconsistent answers are expected for the nouns in the periphery of the schema. This should be observable in the distributions of answers (no clearly distributed response behaviour for nouns in the periphery, predominately acceptance for weak forms but rejection for strong forms regarding nouns belonging to the schema and vice versa for nouns not belonging to the weak declension class) as well as for individual participants (rejection/acceptance for both forms in the periphery, opposite answers to weak and strong forms of a single test noun for nouns belonging to the schema/not belonging to the weak declension class).
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q9: The test items are organized in four blocks. Each block consists of 25 items. In each block, seven to eight test items (two to three test items per level) are included. Strong and weak forms of a single test noun never occur in one block but are spread across blocks. The order of the items within the blocks is constant. The blocks appear in randomized order. The random order is created by randomizing the loops in PsychoPy3.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13:
A sample size of 50 participants is targeted. To reach this number, 100 participants will be recruited. In the prestudy, 12 of 32 participants (38 %) had to be excluded due to missing meta data, response behaviour indicating a lack of concentration and reaction times above 3 sd of the mean reaction times of a level of the category schematicity (e.g., schema). Hence, 50 % more data are collected in order to reach the targeted 50 participants.

See https://osf.io/834nz for the preregistration of the prestudy.  Deviating from the preregistration of the prestudy, participants were exluded if 10 % of the items evaluating the concentration of the participants were answered incorrectly. Additionally, participants werde excluded whose reaction times were above 3 sd from the mean reaction times for a level of the category schematicity (e.g., schema).
registration_responses.q14:
The sample size is set to 50 participants based on a power analysis for the reaction times: 50 participants are required to reach a power of over 0.8 for an alpha level of 0.01 for the estimates 0.22 for the level combination "notweak:weak", 0.14 for the level combination "schema: strong", 0.14 for the level combination "periphery:strong" and -0.42 for the level combination "notweak:strong" of the categories schematicity and inflection.  The estimates were computed with a mixed linear model analysing the data of the prestudy. The data of the prestudy (data_prestudy_schema_decision.csv) as well as the code (prestudy_schema_decision.R) analysing the data is attached. See https://osf.io/834nz for the preregistered analysis plan of the prestudy. The code for the data simulation (power analysis_schema_decision.R) calculating the power based on the estimates of the prestudy for 50 particpants is attached as well. The simulation was repeated 10000 times, a file with 10000 repitions of the simulation is attached (sims_schema_dec.csv). See section "statistical models" for the attached files. The code for the data simulation is based on a tutorial for power analyses with R by DeBruine and Barr (preprint).
Note that the power analysis is based on a model that only uses random intercepts, as the model had convergence issues when random slopes were used. For the main study, random slopes for participants will be included into the modell (see analysis plan).

registration_responses.q8.question:
A within subject design is used with two factors (schematicity and inflection) with three levels (prototype the schema, periphery of the schema, not belonging to the weak class) and two levels (weak, strong), respectively. Per level of schematicity, five test words are used. The test words are presented with weak as well as strong inflection (e.g., des Kollegen/des Kolleges) and participants are asked to decide whether they know the word ("Kennen Sie dieses Wort bzw. diese Wortabfolge?" 'Do you know this word/ word sequence?'). The answer (yes/no) as well as the reaction times are used for data analysis. 
Verbs belonging to the strong conjugation class with weak and strong inflection are used as fillers. They serve as test items for a study on the influence of frequency on variation. Additionally, strong genitive forms ending with -es are used as fillers. The genitive form -es is used for nouns that normally have -s as genitive ending as they do not allow -es phonotactically (*des Abendes 'the evening.GEN') (Szczepaniak 2010).  
To test the design, reaction times elicited by long (-es) and short (-s) genitive endings of two nouns not allowing long genitive endings are contrasted (Ultimatum, Internet) as well as reaction times elicited by regular and irregular forms of the irregular verbs "gehen" 'to go' and "bringen" 'to bring'. These items will only be relevant if the statistical analysis of the test items does not hint to differences in reaction times.  The items allow to test whether the design can elicit differences in reaction times in general. The following mixed linear model will be used  if the design needs to be tested: reaction time ~ acceptance + (1|item)+(1+acceptance|participant). Acceptance is the manipulated variable. The variabel has two levels: accepted (short ending/irregular form) and not accepted (long ending/regular form). Additionally, the response behaviour (yes/no) of the participants will be analysed with the following logistic mixed linear model (response ~ acceptance + (1|item)+(1+form|participant). 

PsychoPy3, version 3.1.5,  (Peirce 2019) is used to implement the study. 

Test items

Prototype of the schema: Franzose ‘frenchman’, Geselle ‘journeyman’, Kollege ‘colleague’, Neffe ‘nephew‘, Schütze ‘marksman‘ 

Periphery of the schema: Fürst ‘ruler’, Graf ‘count’, Held ‘hero’, Nachbar ‘neighbor’, Zar ‘tsar’, 

Not belonging to the weak declension class: Dieb ‘thief’, Feind ‘enemy’, Freund ‘friend’, Kerl ‘guy’, Vogt ‘reeve’

In order to avoid frequency effects, nouns are used that have a frequency of up to two hits per million tokens in 2018 in the word frequencies provided by digital dictionary for the German language (Digitales Wörterbuch der Deutschen Sprache, Berlin-Brandenburgische Akademie der Wissenschaften). However, there are slight differences in frequency within the test words: Three nouns that prototypically match the schema have a frequency of 0.4 to 1.6 hits per million tokens but the other two are less frequent (up to 0.05 hits per million tokens). The words that are in the periphery of the schema have a frequency of 0.3 to 0.9 hits per million tokens. Two of the words not belonging to the weak class have a comparable frequency (0.3 to 0.5 hits per million tokens), but the other three are far less frequent (up to 0.04 hits per million tokens). Hence, the nouns not belonging to the weak declension class tend to be less frequent than the other test words. However, "des Gesellen" and "des Neffen", belonging to the prototype of the schema, are comparable infrequent as these nouns. All in all, the token frequencies of the test words are on a comparable level. Note, however, that the prestudy of a similar experiment using a sentence maze task indicated effects of frequency despite trying to control for frequency (see https://osf.io/bhxpz for the preregistration of the main study for the sentence maze study). 
As the prestudy of the present study does not point to differences due to frequency (see Exploratory Analysis, data_prestudy_schema_decision.csv for the data as well as prestudy_schema_decision.R for the code), an influence of frequency is not expected for the main study but will be tested within an exploratory analysis. See the attached file (testwords.csv) for an overview over the test words and their relative frequencies.

The frequency of the test nouns is estimated using the word frequencies for the year 2018 provided by the Digital Dictionary of the German Language (Digitales Wörterbuch der Deutschen Sprache, Berlin-Brandenburgische Akademie der Wissenschaften). Test nouns are searched in the genitive singular (with the more frequently used ending). In order to avoid false positives, determiners are used in the search (e.g. @des @Kollegen ‘the colleague’).

The attached file (stimulus file.csv) gives an overview over stimuli and filler items. The file contains the following columns:

Stimulus_Art: unique coding for each stimulus 	
Stimulus: the stimulus as presented to the participant	
Schema: coding for the masculine test nouns; levels: Schema, Peripherie, nichtschwach
Frequenz: coding for the test verbs; levels: frequent, infrequ_m, infrequ_o (not relevant for this study)
Akzeptanz: coding for the items testing the design; levels: nichtakzeptiert, akzeptiert	
Evaluation: "ev" highlights the items evaluating the concentration of the participants (if over 10 % of the nouns have been answered wrong, participant will be excluded)	
Flexion: coding for the test verbs and nouns; levels: stark/schwach	
Item: naming the test items in their base form (test nouns and strong verbs which are not relevant for this study)
Formakzeptiert: (expected) acceptence/inacceptance of the forms, j (yes), n (no), b (both)
correctKey: correct response key (based on Fromakzeptiert); levels: f (no), j (yes, both)
Block: block in which the item is presented	
PositionimBlock: position within the block

Further explanation for the columns "Formakzeptiert" and "correctKey": For the test nouns, the coding of these columns followed the hypotheses. For the level "Schema", weak forms were coded as accepted and strong forms as not accepted. The opposite pattern was used for the level "nichtschwach". For "Peripherie" both forms were coded as accepted.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants will be recruited by asking teachers at German universities to distribute the study among their students. If necessary, participants will be addionally recruited out of the personal sphere of the author. The participation in the study is voluntary. The participants will not be paid for participating in the study. Participants are informed that their data is stored and analysed anonymously. Participants that are bilingual (defined as having acquired more than one language before the twelfth year of life), do not speak German as their L1 or have dyslexia will be excluded from the study. Additionally, participants will be excluded whose response behaviour points to them not focussing on the task. This evaluation will be based on 31 items. For these items, participants should not vary in their answers (the 31 items are fillers as well as words that are used in the example block and words that are used to evaluate the design of the study). The cut-off point is set to 10 %. Hence, participants that answer three items or more in the opposite way will be excluded from the study. In addition, participants whose reaction times are above 3 sd of the mean reaction times of a level of the category schematicity (e.g., Schema/Peripherie) are excluded from the sample.
If the design has to be tested (see study design for further explanations), only the filler items as well as the items from the example block will be used to evaluate the participants' reponse behaviour. These are 23 items, hence, the cut-off point will be set to 2 or more items that have been answered in the opposite way in this case.

The study is carried out online using the platform pavlovia.org. The git-project with code and stimulus files can be viewed at https://gitlab.pavlovia.org/eleonore/decision.
registration_responses.q16.question: The schematicity is manipulated by choosing test words that match the schema of weak masculine nouns to different degrees. Three levels are used for this categorial variable: prototype of the schema, periphery of the schema, not belonging to the weak declension class (see study design for an explanation of the levels). The inflection of the test words is manipulated as well. The two levels of this nominal variable are weak and strong.
registration_responses.q17.question:
The outcome variables are the response behaviour (yes/no) and the reaction times for weak and strong forms of masculine nouns belonging to the weak declension class to different degrees (see manipulated variable). This is measured by showing participants weak and strong forms of the test nouns and asking them "Kennen Sie dieses Wort bzw. diese Wortabfolge?" 'Do you know this word/word sequence?'. Additionally to the response behaviour, the time elapsing from the stimulus onset to the response will be measured. 

Meta data (age, gender, dyslexia, educational level, handedness, mother tongue, predominantly speaking dialect or standard, speaking dialect in general, if dialect, which dialect, origin (county, city), current place of residence, intensity of reading (daily, weekly, monthly) is collected. The meta data is used to exclude particpiants from the study (see data collection procedures). It is not used for confirmatory analysis.
registration_responses.q19.question:
For the analysis, R and Rstudio are used (R Core Team 2019, RStudio Team 2015). For the prestudy and the main study, the same version of R and Rstudio are used.

Reaction Times

To calculate the differences in reaction times, a mixed linear model is used. The schematicity of the nouns (prototype of the schema, periphery of the schema, not belonging to the weak class) and the forms (strong, weak) will be included as fixed effects that may interact (high reaction times for nouns that prototypically match the schema with strong endings but low reaction times for the same nouns with weak endings). Item and participant are included as random effects. For participants, random intercepts and random slopes are included, for items only random intercepts as they vary across the levels of the category schematicity. The independent variables are schematicity and the forms. Reaction times are the dependent variable.

Reaction time ~ schematicity * form + (1|item)+ (1+schematicity|participant)

If the model fails to converge, random slopes will be dropped so that only random intercepts are part of the model. 

Acceptance

To evaluate the differences in acceptance (yes/no), a logistic mixed linear model is used. Forms (strong, weak) as well as schematicity (prototype of the schema, periphery of the schema, not belonging to the weak class) are included as fixed effects that may interact (rejection of weak inflection for a noun not belonging to the weak class but not for a noun that matches the schema prototypically). Item and participant are included as random effects. Again, participants are included with random intercepts and random slopes; items only with random intercepts. The independent variables are schematicity and the forms. Acceptance (yes/no) is the dependent variable.

acceptance ~ schematicity * form + (1|item)+ (1+schematicity|participant)

If the model fails to converge, random slopes will be dropped so that only random intercepts are part of the model.

In the prestudy, convergence issues were reported for the generalized linear model so that items had to be dropped as random effect completely (see prestudy_schema_decision.R). Therefore, a conditional inference tree as well as a random forest were calculated additionally. This method will also be used in the main study if the same problems arise for the generalized mixed linear model.

Within the tree and the forest, schematicity as well as inflection will be included as factors:

Key ~ Schema + Inflection

For the tree and the forest, the same code will be used as indicated in the file prestudy_schema_decision.R.
